cn.edu.xjtu.se.jackq

Class MyStringBuilder1

  • java.lang.Object
    • cn.edu.xjtu.se.jackq.MyStringBuilder1
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.lang.CharSequence

    public class MyStringBuilder1
extends java.lang.Object
implements java.lang.CharSequence
    A personal implementation of StringBuilder but it is a simplified version of StringBuilder. This implementation also implemented the CharSequence interface.

    Comparing to String, a StringBuilder provides more flexibility on modification to the character sequence. Here in this implementation, the flexibility is based on an character array.

    As for the capacity consideration during this implementation, Firstly, choose a generally acceptable capacity which is enough for most common scenarios and here is 80. When the character array isn't capable to contain all of characters, it will generate a new array with another 80-character capacity.

    Author:
    Jack Q (qiaobo@outlook.com)
    See Also:
    StringBuilder, CharSequence

    • Field Detail

      • MINIMUM_CAPACITY

        private static final int MINIMUM_CAPACITY
        Default capacity of the internal character array

        This value is used to initial objects. Besides, this value is also minimum capacity expanded during expansion.

        See the use of this field in ensureCapacity(int)

      • append

        public MyStringBuilder1 append(java.lang.CharSequence s,
                               int begin,
                               int end)
        Append characters to current buffer form a class which implemented the CharSequence interface. Some commonly used classes have already implemented this interface including String, StringBuilder, StringBuffer, etc
        Parameters:
        s - the source of character from which characters will be appended to current buffer
        begin - the start index of the character in that buffer. The begin-th character is included
        end - the end index of the character in that buffer. The end-th character in excluded
        Returns:
        a reference to current object
        Throws:
        java.lang.NegativeArraySizeException - if the end argument isn't larger than begin
